Merrick had a successful first week back to school. On Sept. 8, once again the hallways of Birch, Levy Lakeside and Chatterton schools were bustling with students, eager to make new friends and reconnect with old ones.

Teachers welcomed students, including those working remotely, to their new learning environments and safely initiated ice-breaking activities for classmates to connect.

During the first two weeks, students enrolled in in-person instruction will be divided into two cohorts as part of the district’s phased reopening plan. All students, besides those who chose to participate in the Alternate Voluntary Remote Program, will return to full-time, in-person instruction starting on Sept. 21.

We look forward to an exciting 2020-2021 school year!

With appropriate caution as a community, we will help limit the impact of this pandemic.

I wish you health and happiness in these difficult times.

Dominick Palma
Superintendent of Schools

In recognition of Agricultural Literacy Week, Birch School welcomed Patricia Voll, master gardener and volunteer from Cornell Cooperative Extension of Nassau County to speak to second-graders about how the soil and environment are used to grow healthy vegetables. Voll brought different types of vegetables that are grown at Cornell’s horticulture center and farm in East Meadow. She also gave students insight into farming and how the vegetables grown through the cooperative are prepared for local markets and even donated to food banks.
Students will put their knowledge to good use this spring as they plant seeds to grow vegetables of their own in the school garden. Birch teacher Mindy Seltzber arranged Voll’s visit to the second-grade classes.

Keeping with Birch School tradition, kindergartners were treated to a visit from a special guest during their celebration of Dr. Seuss’ birthday on March 1, as the always-engaging Cat in the Hat stopped by to greet youngsters and encourage them to continue reading.
During his visit, the Cat asked students to tell him about their favorite Dr. Seuss books, while he shared some fun facts about himself, including his favorite president – “President Garfield” – and his favorite dessert – “tuna pudding” – as well as other interesting “cat-eristics.” The Cat also read to students.
What the surprised students didn’t know is that the Cat was actually Superintendent of Schools Dr. Dominick Palma, who annually slips on the Cat in the Hat suit to visit Birch kindergartners.

Wells novel “The War of the Worlds.” Under the direction of the school’s music teacher Dr. Richard Nastro, students learned about the story, the Oct. 30, 1938, broadcast delivered by Orson Welles over the CBS radio network and the news debacle that followed.
Students took an edited script of the original Mercury Theatre broadcast and have been recording it in step with the original broadcast. They also have been adding musical performances as interludes and creating sound effects where appropriate through the [Patrick] Foley technique of using inanimate objects and other resources at their disposal.

Students, staff, district officials and visitors celebrated visiting veterans at Levy Lakeside School on Nov. 8 as part of the Merrick School District’s annual Veterans Day celebration.

Thirteen local veterans, along with Assemblyman David McDonough, a veteran in his own right, were welcomed into the gymnasium for some celebratory festivities. After the color guard was presented by the fifth-grade student council, all in attendance recited the Pledge of Allegiance and sang “The Star-Spangled Banner” in unison.

Students heard remarks from Principal Elizabeth Trencheny, McDonough and fifth-grader Aaditya. Mr. Al Belbol presented the veterans to the students, who cheered them on veraciously.

“I want you to look at all of these gentlemen sitting up here with me,” McDonough said to Lakeside students. “They are veterans who have served in our military, and because of them, you are able to have what you have today.”

“Veterans often travel far distances to unknown lands,” Additya said. “They give up their lives to protect others. That’s what I call a hero.”

In recognition of National Fire Safety Awareness Week, members of the Merrick Fire Department once again conducted a hands-on lesson with students at Chatterton Elementary School. Merrick F.D. members gave demonstrations on the proper use of Firematics gear and protective clothing as well as the proper technique for exiting a fire situation safely. Students were also treated to a close-up look at some of the department’s trucks and learned how the truck’s apparatus is used to save lives.
Fire officials also advised students to remind their parents to check their home smoke detectors regularly and identify a safe outdoor meeting place in the event of an evacuation. The younger grade level students received fire hats to take home with them. Some even witnessed the F.D. members spring into action, responding to an emergency call shortly after wrapping up their presentation.
We thank the Merrick Fire Department for dedicating their time to teach our students these valuable lessons each year!

Fourth-graders at Chatterton School enjoyed a PTA Cultural Arts in-house field trip called “Journeys Into American Indian Territory.” The daylong program began with an opening assembly in the gymnasium followed by a visit to the Eastern Woodlands Museum, which consisted of a model longhouse large enough for students to walk through. There were genuine furs, baskets, rattles, and other items to see and touch. Overall, students experienced more than 70 different artifacts, representing the Iroquois and Algonquian culture of the Long Island region.

In addition to the museum, fourth-graders enjoyed traditional Native American games and stories, a lesson on the Iroquois government, a clay workshop, and a closing music and dance ceremony in the all-purpose room.

Special thanks to the Chatterton PTA for bringing authentic Native American teachings to students without them ever having to leave school.

Abbe Cohen’s fourth-grade class at Birch School recently took on the role of engineers and became problem-solvers for the farming industry during an educational and important project designed at slowing and preventing soil erosion.

Students learned how running water can change the shape of land and were tasked with helping a farmer deal with heavy rainstorms that were eroding crop soil, thus inhibiting crop growth. Each student was asked to develop a small-scale model of a hillside in order to slow or prevent the water flow from effecting the land.

First, each student set out to identify the best materials to build an effective hillside model, then diagrammed their models and planned solutions to test. Along the way, each chose a method for measuring the rate of erosion and brainstormed ways to change how water flows down their hillside. Once completed, they tested their models and identified variables to change and maintain, even analyzing their own testing procedures to ensure a successful outcome to keep their farmland suitable for cultivating crops.

Birch School second-graders recently participated in a hands-on boatbuilding project to learn about the engineering design process. Students accepted the challenge by working collaboratively in the school’s STEAM lab to design boats that can float and move with the wind.

Working in pairs, students were first asked to brainstorm ideas and develop their own list of materials, then create their boats using materials such as aluminum foil, popsicle sticks and plastic bottles. They learned that a good boat is watertight (with no holes), and possesses tall sides and a wide bottom with a sail tall enough and sturdy enough to catch the wind. Once completed, they set sail, testing their boats in water for buoyancy and experiencing much success!

Every Merrick second-grader will participate in this boatbuilding project, with Chatterton and Levy Lakeside schools scheduled for later this month. Pictured are students in Kimberly DePalma’s class.

Each pumpkin character included a brief description highlighting why they chose the character along with their pumpkin.

Students and staff were delighted to walk past the pumpkins, which are displayed by the main office.Harry Potter, Rainbow Fish, Mrs. Potts and Chip, The Lorax, and Curious George were just a few of the characters to grace Chatterton hallways through the school’s annula Halloween parade.

Chatterton School students learned about the importance of energy and effective conservation practices during a PSEG Long Island-sponsored assembly by the Energized Guyz.

The program incorporated multiple characters and explored four main topics: defining energy, the uses of energy, how energy is wasted and ways to conserve it. One of the main charcaters was Nikki Neutron, a junior superhero on a mission to stop energy from being wasted all over town. Throughout the show, Nikki taught students about various energy conservation methods and methods to cut down energy waste around their homes.

Following the presentations, teachers reinforced topics learned during the performance with classroom activities on energy. This cultural arts assembly was made possible thanks to the Chatterton PTA and PSEGLI. Chatterton students can now consider themselves part of the Energized Guys Team of superheroes that save resources and save the day!

To view a video from the assembly, please click here: http://www.merrick.k12.ny.us/pages/Merrick_UFSD/News/Energized_Heroes

Students at Chatterton School were recently treated to two age-appropriate bully prevention programs through the PTA Cultural Arts program. Through a series of interactive skits and role-playing with members of the student audience, presenters with the Power of One program delivered strong messages to help students through bullying situations. Situations involving exclusion, cyberbullying and physical bullying, as well as how to report bullying, were all covered in an entertaining, uplifting and unifying assembly.

At the conclusion of the program, students recited a pledge to report bullying whenever they see it. A written antibullying pledge was also circulated throughout the school for every student to sign. The pledge will be displayed on posters in the building to serve as visual reminder of the lessons learned, and to reinforce that every individual, no matter how big or small, has the power to stand up to bullying.

The program was held in conjunction with National Bullying Prevention month.

post_text: On September 11, 2017, the entire Levy Lakeside School family gathered together to pay tribute to the events that occurred 16 years prior on September 11, 2001. It was a time of great sadness for our country, but the focus of our ceremony that Monday morning was the lesson that came out of that fateful day in our nation's history. After saying the Pledge of Allegiance and singing the National Anthem, students Jack S. and Jacob F. shared important messages regarding unity and pride in nation. Mr. Glemboski also led the school in singing, Proud to Be an American.
